headline: Budget 2025: Government Unveils Business Tax Cuts and KiwiSaver Overhaul, Sparking Fierce Opposition Over Pay Equity Savings
summary: The government unveiled its 2025 Budget, a package centered on fiscal restraint and long-term growth through a significant new business tax incentive called 'Investment Boost'. Finance Minister Nicola Willis described it as a responsible plan to secure the country's future, funding boosts to health and education through savings from KiwiSaver changes and a contentious overhaul of the pay equity regime. The Opposition immediately attacked the plan, arguing it was funded on the backs of working women and would leave New Zealanders worse off in retirement.

topicSummaries.topic: Government Unveils 'Investment Boost' and Savings-Funded Spending
topicSummaries.content: Finance Minister Nicola Willis presented a Budget focused on fiscal discipline, aiming to control spending and return the government's books to surplus. The centerpiece is a new 'Investment Boost' policy, allowing businesses to immediately deduct 20% of the cost of new assets from their taxable income. The Budget also increases spending in health, education, and defence, funded in large part by over $5 billion in annual savings. These savings are primarily drawn from halving the government's contribution to KiwiSaver and repurposing $2.7 billion a year from contingencies previously set aside for pay equity claims, a move the government said was necessary to correct a broken system.

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon Nicola Willis (New Zealand National)
keyExchanges.quote: This is a responsible Budget to secure New Zealand's future. It supports the economic recovery now under way. It does all of this with an expenditure track that reduces Government spending as a share of the economy, returns the Government's books to balance, and bends the debt curve down.

keyExchanges.speaker: Rt Hon Christopher Luxon (New Zealand National)
keyExchanges.quote: For a second year in a row, she's knocked it completely out of the park. Thank you, Nicola Willis. Now, Budget 2025 is a responsible Budget, and it is focused on growth, and it is focused on helping Kiwis get ahead.

topicSummaries.topic: Opposition Slams Budget as an 'Attack on Working Women'
topicSummaries.content: The Opposition, led by Labour's Chris Hipkins, launched a blistering attack on the Budget, framing it as an act of austerity funded by cuts that disproportionately harm women. The central criticism was aimed at the government's decision to repurpose billions from the pay equity contingency fund. Hipkins argued this amounted to devaluing the work of women in critical sectors like healthcare and education to pay for tax breaks for landlords and corporations. The government countered that the previous pay equity regime was unaffordable and unworkable, and that the changes were a sensible fiscal decision.

keyExchanges.speaker: Rt Hon Chris Hipkins (New Zealand Labour)
keyExchanges.quote: This is the Budget that said to working Kiwi women, they are worth less—in fact, nearly $3 billion a year less. A Budget that says that women are worth less than tax breaks for landlords.

keyExchanges.speaker: Rt Hon Christopher Luxon (New Zealand National)
keyExchanges.quote: Labour's regime was unworkable, it was broken, it was unaffordable. We've made the sensible changes, and yes, we've saved $12 billion in doing so.

topicSummaries.topic: Major KiwiSaver Overhaul Sparks Retirement Savings Debate
topicSummaries.content: The Budget introduces significant changes to KiwiSaver, aimed at boosting savings while making the scheme more fiscally sustainable. The default contribution rate for employees and employers will be gradually lifted from 3% to 4%, and eligibility will be extended to 16 and 17-year-olds. However, to generate savings, the annual government contribution will be halved to a maximum of around $260, and it will be eliminated for individuals earning over $180,000. The government stated the changes would lead to larger retirement balances, while the opposition claimed it was a raid on savings that would leave young workers tens of thousands of dollars worse off.

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon Nicola Willis (New Zealand National)
keyExchanges.quote: Putting all these changes together, the KiwiSaver balances of employees contributing at the new default rate will grow faster than they do now, providing a larger balance at age 65 or when people come to buy their first home—building the financial security of New Zealanders.

keyExchanges.speaker: Rt Hon Chris Hipkins (New Zealand Labour)
keyExchanges.quote: An 18-year-old New Zealander, as of this year's Budget, is now going to be $66,000 worse off in their retirement. Let's be clear on that.

topicSummaries.content: Following the Budget announcement and initial debate, the government moved a motion of urgency to fast-track the passage of several pieces of implementing legislation. The most significant is the Taxation (Budget Measures) Bill (No 2), which enacts the 'Investment Boost' tax incentive, the KiwiSaver changes, and adjustments to Working for Families. The government argued urgency was necessary to provide certainty and allow measures like the Investment Boost to take effect immediately. The Opposition used the urgent debate to continue its attack, arguing the bill's measures were being paid for by cuts that harm working families and women.

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon Nicola Willis (New Zealand National)
keyExchanges.quote: These are meaningful, forward-looking tax changes that will help boost wages, savings, and growth. These are changes that will help families who most need financial support.

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon Dr Deborah Russell (New Zealand Labour)
keyExchanges.quote: The person who will be answering to the New Zealand public... is the person who has balanced this Budget on the backs of working women, on the backs of families, and on the backs of low-paid workers who rely on that Government contribution to KiwiSaver.

conclusion: As Parliament began an urgent debate on the implementing legislation late into the night, the day's events solidified a stark political battleground between the government's focus on fiscal discipline and business-led growth versus the opposition's charge of austerity funded by the vulnerable.
